reasoning: The query explores the relationship between university fees and educational quality. To expand the query and understand its evolution, we'll analyze historical perspectives on funding models, key milestones in educational reform, current debates surrounding free tuition, and potential future trends in higher education financing.
augmented_query: "impact of university funding models on educational quality throughout history, alternative higher education finance models, future trends in student affordability and access"
query: The quality of education suffers when university education is free  Without university fees, universities become dependent on the state for funding. This leads to larger class­sizes and less spending per student. [1] Yet with fees, the quality of universities increases for three reasons. First, funding improves, as university may charge in accordance with need. Second, quality of teaching is improved. Because a university wants people to attend and to pay fees, the programs and degrees they offer have to be good signals of quality requiring hiring the best lecturers. Third, the average quality of students attending university will improve. This is because students feel they need to get the most from their investment in education. An example of higher quality education from fee­paying is that of the United States, which has eighteen of the top fifty ranked universities in the world. [2] Quality is clearly improved when university is not free.  [1] Brady, Hugh. 2008. “We Must Invest Now in Our Universities or Pay Later”. University College Dublin News Available:  ents.html​  [2] QS World University Rankings 2015/16, QS,
historical_foundation: Early universities (Medieval period): Largely funded by churches and wealthy patrons
Emphasis on classical studies and religious instruction
Concept of 'scholarship' as a means of merit-based access
development_milestones: 19th Century: Rise of public universities and state funding
20th Century: Expansion of higher education access, increased government investment
Late 20th - Early 21st Century: Emergence of tuition fees as a primary revenue source for many universities
Growing debate on the impact of fees on accessibility and quality
current_landscape: Public funding vs. tuition fees as key funding models
Concerns about rising costs and student debt
Discussions on alternative funding mechanisms (e.g., income-based repayment)
Emphasis on accountability and performance metrics in higher education
emerging_trends: Online learning and MOOCs potentially disrupting traditional funding structures
Increased focus on skills-based education aligned with workforce needs
Potential for greater government subsidies or grants to address affordability concerns
cleaned_augmented_query: impact university funding models educational quality throughout history alternative higher education finance future trends student affordability access
initial_results:
### Text snippet from document at k=1
... Having Private universities clearly creams off the best students and the funding leaving the public universities in a worse position lowering the overall quality of education.  1 Shepherd, Jessica, "What universities think of competing for their admissions." Guardian.co.uk, 28 June 2011. 2 Hotson, Howard, "Don't Look to the Ivy League." London Review of Books, Vol.33, No.10, 19 May 2011 .

### Text snippet from document at k=2
: The introduction of more private universities would increase the quality of education by allowing open competition  In the rest of the economy, when consumers are allowed to choose between goods or services, the higher quality products are successful and the bad ones fail. Similarly, when consumers can makes choices between universities, and are putting money on the line (thus taking a risk) they will choose the good universities, and consider the bad universities as not worth wasting their money on. As a consequence, the best universities will expand, and the worst universities will either improve or fail. The New College of the Humanities for example is aiming to rival Oxford and Cambridge1 so helping to provide these two elite institutions with the necessary competition to force up standards. This will result in a higher quality of education being available to more people.  1 BBC News, "Academics launch £18,000 college in London.” 5 June 2011

### Text snippet from document at k=10
: The cost to the state is far too great to sustain universal free university education  The system of paying for universal healthcare, education, pensions, etc. threatens to bankrupt countries. The cost of paying for free university education is ruinously high. [1] In the OECD 1.9% of GDP, a third of education expenditure, is spent on tertiary education. [2] For countries to survive, they must rethink what they can afford to provide freely to citizens. It seems fair that all states should offer access to their citizens to primary and secondary education opportunities. University, on the other hand, is not essential to life in the same way. People can be functional and responsible citizens without it. For this reason, the state must consider university in the same way it does any non­essential service; people may pay for it if they wish to partake, but it is not an entitlement owed by the state.  [1] Ullman, Ben. 2007. “Should Higher Education Really Be Free For All?”. The New Statesman. Available:  ­radicals/2007/01/higher­education­free­students  [2] ‘What proportion of national wealth is spent on education’, Education at a glance, OECD, 2011, p.225,
thought_process:
As I begin to explore the query "The quality of education suffers when university education is free," my initial impression is that this statement might be controversial and could have various perspectives. The user might be trying to understand the relationship between university fees and educational quality, but it's also possible they're looking for arguments to support or refute the idea that free university education leads to lower quality. My first instinct is to consider the potential consequences of free university education on funding models, teacher quality, and student motivation.

Analyzing the results of the original query, I notice that the text snippets highlight different aspects of the debate. Some argue that private universities and competition can improve education quality, while others point out the financial burden of free university education on the state. I see strengths in the search terms, such as the focus on university fees and educational quality, but I also notice weaknesses, like the lack of historical context and the limited consideration of alternative funding models.

To expand the query, I'll use the Temporal Evolution Analysis technique, which involves exploring how the topic has evolved over time and will likely develop in the future. This technique should help me discover temporally diverse terminology and provide a more comprehensive understanding of the query.

Starting with the Historical Foundation, I'll examine the origins and early development of university funding models. I note that early universities were largely funded by churches and wealthy patrons, with an emphasis on classical studies and religious instruction. The concept of 'scholarship' as a means of merit-based access is also relevant here.

As I move through the Developmental Milestones, I identify key evolutionary stages in university funding, such as the rise of public universities and state funding in the 19th century, and the expansion of higher education access in the 20th century. I also note the emergence of tuition fees as a primary revenue source for many universities and the growing debate on the impact of fees on accessibility and quality.

In the Current Landscape, I assess the contemporary state of university funding models, including the emphasis on accountability and performance metrics in higher education. I also note the concerns about rising costs and student debt, as well as discussions on alternative funding mechanisms, such as income-based repayment.

Finally, in Emerging Horizons, I project how university funding models are likely to evolve, including the potential for greater government subsidies or grants to address affordability concerns, and the impact of online learning and MOOCs on traditional funding structures.

Through this process, I've identified a range of temporally diverse terms, from "Medieval" to "Digital Age," which provide historical context and future relevance. I've also considered the evolution of concepts, such as the shift from church-funded to state-funded universities, and the emergence of new terminology, like "income-based repayment" and "MOOCs."

As I synthesize my findings, I believe the expanded query "impact university funding models educational quality throughout history alternative higher education finance future trends student affordability access" effectively captures the complexities of the original query. This expanded query considers the historical evolution of university funding models, alternative finance models, and future trends in student affordability and access, providing a more comprehensive understanding of the relationship between university fees and educational quality.
